text.p: The following are the main stories from Thursday morning's German newspapers:
FRANKFURTER ALLGEMEINE ZEITUNG

- Chancellor Helmut Kohl's ruling Christian Democrats (CDU) agree in principle to pension reform proposal by Labour Minister Norbert Bluem, which would reduce the value of pensions to 64 percent of net pay by 2030 from 70 percent now.
- Confrontation diffused between steelmakers Krupp and Thyssen as Krupp postpones its hostile bid and offers to talk about combining steel businesses.
- Opposition Social Democrats (SPD) want legal foundation for emergency operations by the German army outside of the NATO area.
- Syrian Foreign Minister Farouq al-Shara welcomes role of Europe in Middle East peace process.
HANDELSBLATT
- Hostile takeover of Thyssen by Krupp is avoided for the time being as the two companies negotiate over creating a joint steel company.
- CDU mini-party congress votes in favour of Labour Minister Bluem's pension reform proposal.
- Kohl declines to restart talks with SPD over planned tax reform after Kohl receives letter from SPD leader Oskar Lafontaine laying out party's demands.
- The Bundesbank's top indicator, M3 money supply growth, slowed to 9.1 percent in February, compared to an alarming 11.7 percent in January.
- Officials find serious violation of new minimum wage rules in building sector.
SUEDDEUTSCHE ZEITUNG
- Krupp wants to negotiate with Thyssen over possible merger of steel businesses. Hostile takover avoided, but workers' councils still see danger of loss of 30,000 jobs.
- Southern state of Bavaria increases border controls because of the rising number of refugees from Albania.
- World Health Organisation (WHO) reports breakthrough in the fight against turberculosis.
- The deadlock over talks on planned tax reforms between Chancellor Kohl and opposition Social Democrats (SPD) continue as a compromise deal seems to become more and more unlikely.
DIE WELT
- Kohl declines to meet Lafontaine for new talks on planned tax reform and says the SPD leader should meet Finance Minister Theo Waigel instead.
- Hostile takeover of Thyssen by Krupp avoided as firms negotiate, but workers' protests continue.
- CDU agrees to Labour Minister Bluem's pension reform proposal.
